sections.title: Introduction
content: Deep Learning (DL) is a subset of Machine Learning that uses artificial neural networks for complex pattern recognition.
It consists of multiple layers that automatically learn feature representations from data.
DL is used in applications such as speech recognition, image classification, and natural language processing.
Hierarchical Learning extracts features at multiple levels of abstraction.
DL performs well with large datasets and high-dimensional data.
End-to-End Training reduces the need for manual feature engineering.

sections.title: Biological Inspiration
content: Artificial neurons mimic biological neurons in transmitting signals.
Synaptic weights in artificial networks represent learned associations.
Activation functions simulate the firing behavior of biological neurons.
Hebbian Learning states that neurons that fire together, wire together.
Reinforcement of connections between frequently activated neurons forms the foundation of unsupervised learning in neural networks.

sections.title: Architectural Components
content: Dense (Fully Connected) layers connect every neuron to all neurons in the next layer.
Convolutional layers capture spatial patterns using local receptive fields.
Recurrent layers process sequential data using memory cells (LSTMs, GRUs).
LeakyReLU allows small negative values, preventing dead neurons.
Swish and GELU activation functions improve training stability and expressiveness.
Batch Normalization normalizes activations across mini-batches.
Self-Attention computes relationships between all input tokens.
Multi-Head Attention enhances the model's ability to capture multiple dependencies.

sections.title: Advanced Architectures
content: Transformers use self-attention mechanisms instead of recurrence for sequential data processing.
They enable parallel processing and have revolutionized NLP and vision models.
Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) consist of a Generator and a Discriminator in a competitive learning setup.
GANs are used for image generation, style transfer, and data augmentation.

sections.title: Training Methods
content: Backpropagation Through Time (BPTT) is a variant of backpropagation for training recurrent neural networks.
It unrolls the network in time to handle dependencies in sequential data.
Curriculum Learning Strategies introduce easier examples first, gradually increasing complexity.
Inspired by human learning, this strategy stabilizes training and improves convergence.

sections.title: Applications
content: Deep learning models detect diseases from X-rays, MRIs, and CT scans.
Used for cancer detection, brain tumor segmentation, and retinal disease diagnosis.
Neural machine translation (NMT) models enable fast, accurate translations.
Transformer-based architectures improve context understanding for real-time translation.

Definition and Overview: Natural Language Processing (NLP) enables machines to understand and generate human language.
Combines linguistics, computer science, and artificial intelligence.
Used in applications like chatbots, translation, and sentiment analysis.

Tokenization: Splits text into smaller units (words, subwords, or characters).
WordPiece and SentencePiece improve tokenization for unseen words.
Essential for preprocessing in NLP models.
Syntax Analysis: Dependency parsing identifies relationships between words.
Part-of-Speech (POS) tagging labels words with grammatical categories.
Used for grammar checking and information extraction.
Semantic Understanding: Word Sense Disambiguation (WSD) determines correct word meanings.
Named Entity Recognition (NER) identifies proper nouns in text.
Essential for accurate machine translation and summarization.
Pragmatics: Contextual interpretation considers speaker intent and tone.
Crucial for sentiment analysis and sarcasm detection.

Word Embeddings: Word2Vec and GloVe map words to high-dimensional vectors.
Limitations: Static representations lack context awareness.
Contextual Embeddings: ELMo uses bidirectional LSTMs for context-dependent word representations.
BERT improves embeddings with deep bidirectional learning.
Enable better understanding of word meanings in different contexts.
Knowledge-Enhanced Representations: Integrate external knowledge bases like Wikidata and ConceptNet.
Used in question-answering and fact-checking systems.
Multilingual Embedding Spaces: Align word representations across multiple languages.
Used in machine translation and multilingual search.

Transformer Variants: BERT captures context in both directions.
GPT generates coherent text using unidirectional learning.
T5 treats all NLP tasks as text generation problems.
Retrieval-Augmented Models: Use external databases to enhance language understanding.
Improve accuracy in question-answering and summarization tasks.
Sparse Attention Mechanisms: Reduce computational costs of attention mechanisms.
Used in long-form text processing like summarization.
Example: Longformer model for handling long documents.
Mixture-of-Experts Approaches: Divide computations among multiple smaller models (experts).
Enhance efficiency and specialization for different NLP tasks.

Conversational AI: Use reinforcement learning and memory networks.
Examples: ChatGPT, Google Bard, and Siri.
Text Summarization: Used in news aggregation and document summarization.
Sentiment Analysis: Determines opinions and emotions in text.
Aspect-based approaches analyze sentiments toward specific topics.
Used in customer feedback analysis and brand monitoring.
Knowledge Extraction: Relation mining identifies links between entities.
Used for building structured knowledge bases.

Low-Resource Language Processing: Many languages lack large-scale annotated datasets.
Few-shot and zero-shot learning approaches address this issue.
Multilingual NLP models help bridge the gap.
Commonsense Reasoning: AI struggles with implicit knowledge and logical reasoning.
Benchmarks like the Winograd Schema Challenge test AI’s reasoning ability.
Knowledge-enhanced NLP models aim to improve commonsense understanding.
Multimodal Understanding: Combines text, images, and audio for deeper comprehension.
Used in video captioning and voice assistants.
Example: CLIP and DALL·E models by OpenAI.
Ethical Text Generation: Mitigating biases in language models is challenging.
Ensuring AI-generated text aligns with ethical guidelines.
Developing safe and responsible AI applications.
